contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox person | image = Jørgen Ingmann.jpg | name = Jørgen Ingmann | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1925|4|26|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Denmark]] | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | occupation = [[musician]] | years_active = 1944 - 1984 | Notable instrument = Gibson Les Paul }} '''Jørgen Ingmann''' (born 26 April 1925) is a [[musician]] from [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. He worked with [[Svend Asmussen]], the jazz violinist, during the 1940s and part of the 1950s. During the late 1950s he changed his stage name to '''Jørgen Ingmann and his guitar'''. Under this name he recorded "[[Apache (instrumental)|Apache]]" in 1961, which charted at #1 in [[Canada]] on the [[CHUM Chart]], #2 in the [[United States]] on the ''Billboard'' pop singles chart, #9 on the ''Billboard'' R&B chart, #4 on ''Cashbox'', and #6 in [[Germany]].<ref>[http://tsort.info/music/yr1961.htm 1961 Chart.tsort.info.]</ref><ref>[http://www.cashboxcountdowns.com/archives/60s_files/1961YESP.html 1961 ''Cashbox'' Year End Chart.]</ref> He remade [[Silvana Mangano]]'s "Anna" with moderate US chart success.<ref>The single reached #54; Joel Whitburn: ''Top Pop Singles 1955-1993''. Menomonee Falls / Wisconsin: Record Research Ltd. 1994, p. 290</ref> In the first half of the 1960s he had many hits in Germany like "Pepe" (1961 #15), "Anna" (1961 #19), "Violetta" (1962 #16), "[[Marš na Drinu|Drina Marsch]]" (1964 #5) and "Zorba le Grec" (1965 #14).<ref>Günter Ehnert (ed.): ''Hit Bilanz. Deutsche Chart Singles 1956-1980''. Hamburg: Taurus Press 1990, p. 105</ref> ''Billboard'' magazine reported that he charted at no. 2 on the Denmark pop singles chart with his recording of "[[Marš na Drinu|Marchen Til Drina]]" on 7 December 1963.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=SAsEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA28&lpg=PA28&dq=billboard+december+7+1963+ingmann&source=bl&ots=x89G3-Ubsl&sig=hIKnisKbdiRj ''Billboard'', December 7, 1963.]</ref> His recording reached no. 1 on 17 December 1963.<ref>[http://www.danpop.dk/631217.html Danish Top 20 Chart.]</ref> Songs of his included "[[Tequila (song)|Tequila]]" (which he also recorded during the 60s, with the Champs) and a version of [[Pinetop Perkins]]' "Pinetop's Boogie Woogie" (from 1962). He worked as a member of the duet, [[Grethe and Jørgen Ingmann|Grethe og Jørgen Ingmann]], together with his wife Grethe Ingmann. After winning the [[Dansk Melodi Grand Prix]] competition in 1963, they went on to represent Denmark at the [[Eurovision Song Contest]] where they won with the song "[[Dansevise]]" (Dance Ballad), music by [[Otto Francker]] and lyrics by [[Sejr Volmer-Sørensen]]. He and Grethe met in 1955, married in 1956, and divorced in 1975. ==References== <references /> ==External links== {{commonscat|Jørgen Ingmann}} *{{MusicBrainz artist|id=67e5cdc2-7bf2-4942-930a-c8e3f308429f|name=Jørgen Ingmann}} {{S-start}} {{S-ach}} {{Succession box| before={{flagicon|France}} [[Isabelle Aubret]]<br> with ''[[Un premier amour]]'' | title=[[List of Eurovision Song Contest winners|Winner of the Eurovision Song Contest]] | years=[[Eurovision Song Contest 1963|1963]]<br>(with [[Grethe Ingmann]])| after={{flagicon|Italy}} [[Gigliola Cinquetti]]<br> with ''[[Non ho l'età]]'' }} {{S-end}} {{Eurovision winners}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Ingmann, Jorgen | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Danish musician | DATE OF BIRTH =26 April 1925 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Denmark]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ingmann, Jorgen}} {{Denmark-singer-stub}} {{Denmark-musician-stub}} {{Guitarist-stub}} [[Category:1925 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Danish male singers]] [[Category:Danish guitarists]] [[Category:Eurovision Song Contest winners]] [[Category:Danish Eurovision Song Contest entrants]] [[Category:Eurovision Song Contest entrants of 1963]]
